section.title: Quick Start Guide
section.para: RestComm is a robust, powerful platform that will facilitate building comprehensive real-time communication solutions. The steps below will help you get started with ease.

note.para: Running a secure application is dependent on multiple factors. Restcomm runs on JBoss which implies that system security implemention can be handled at JBoss level. Please see the link below on how you can make your server environment more secure.

section.title: Testing the Demo Applications
section.para: Restcomm comes prepackaged with multiple example applications designed to help you quickly get started.

section.title: Demo 1 - Testing the Play Verb
section.para: Start a SIP phone (see below) and dial 1234@127.0.0.1:5080 . You will hear a welcome message.
section.warning: Some SIP phones have codec incompatibility issues, in the above example, we used Ekiga. You may also try Jitsi or Sflphone.
section.programlisting: The application bound to the number 1234 can be found at <filename>$RESTCOMM_HOME/standalone/deployments/restcomm.war/demos/hello-play.xml</filename>.

section.title: Demo 2 - Testing Say Verb
section.para: You must first activate Text-to-Speech before you can proceed.

You must get an API key from http://www.voicerss.org in order to proceed with this section. You can register for a free account and an API key will be emailed to you. Once you have the API key, open the $RESTCOMM_HOME/standalone/deployments/restcomm.war/WEB-INF/conf/restcomm.xml file and find the speech-synthesizer VoiceRSS section. Add your API key as shown below and restart RestComm
Start a SIP phone dial 1235@127.0.0.1:5080 . You will hear a welcome message in multiple languages.
section.programlisting: The application bound to the number 1235 can be found at $RESTCOMM_HOME/standalone/deployments/restcomm.war/demos/hello-world.xml.

section.title: Demo 3 - Testing Gather Verb
section.para: This demo creates a simple IVR system

note.title: Activate DTMF using Ekiga
note.para: Make sure your DTMF setting in Ekiga is set to RFC2833. In order to set it correctly, go to the menu Edit->Preference->Protocols->SIP Settings->DTMF Mode
You may also use SFLPHONE instead of Ekiga

section.para: Start a SIP phone dial 1236@127.0.0.1:5080 . You will hear a message asking you to enter a digit and press star. If the digit is correctly received, Restcomm will replay the number you entered.
section.programlisting: The application bound to the number 1236 can be found at <filename>$RESTCOMM_HOME/standalone/deployments/restcomm.war/demos/gather/hello-gather.xml</filename>. and <filename>$RESTCOMM_HOME/standalone/deployments/restcomm.war/demos/gather/gather.jsp</filename>.

section.title: Demo 4 - Testing the Dial Sip Noun
section.para: This demo makes a call from one SIP phone to another. The Demo uses the SIP noun. You can calll any SIP account. All you have to do is change the content of the dial-sip.xml

In order to use this demo, you may use the default accounts, Alice and Bob, and register them on two separate SIP phones. Start both SIP phones and make sure Alice and Bob are registerd with the password (1234). These users come pre-configured with Restcomm for test purposes.

note.title: Start Two SIP Phone Sessions
note.para: If you are using the SIP sflphone here is what to do:
Start second instance ex. - sudo sflphone

section.para: In the application dial-sip.xml you can change the default to sip:alice@127.0.0.1:5061?
This will allow you to make a call to Alice. Note that Alice must be registered on port 5061 for the call to succeed.
From the the phone on which Bob is registerd, dial the number 1237 . The phone on which Alice is registered will ring and the connection will be made when you answer the call.
section.programlisting: The application bound to the number 1237 can be found at $RESTCOMM_HOME/standalone/deployments/restcomm.war/demos/dial/sip/dial-sip.xml.

section.title: Demo 5 - Testing the Client Noun
section.para: This demo makes a call from one SIP Client to Another. The demo uses the Client noun

In order to use this demo, you must have user Alice and Bob registered on two separate SIP phones. Start both SIP phones and make sure Alice and Bob are registerd with the password (1234). These users come pre-configured with Restcomm for test purposes.

section.programlisting: The application bound to the number 1238 can be found at <filename>$RESTCOMM_HOME/standalone/deployments/restcomm.war/demos/dial/client/dial-client.xml</filename>.

section.title: Detailed Configuration
section.para: In order for TelScale RestComm to function properly it must first be configured. In this chapter we will cover the settings for TelScale RestComm and it's respective plug-ins. In order to make TelScale RestComm easy to manage all of the configuration is done in only one file. The file is located at RESTCOMM_HOME/WEB-INF/webapps/restcomm/conf/restcomm.xml and is composed of the sections that follow.

note.para: TelScale RestComm provides a default set of plug-ins for the storage engine, fax service, SMS aggregator, automatic speech recognition, and speech synthesis. All these services are pluggable and TelScale RestComm is not limited to any service provider or software platformz.

formalpara.title: TelScale Restcomm Resource Security
formalpara.para: The security model is based on role based access control. TelScale RestComm defines a set of permissions that can be defined for each role. There are two predefined roles Administrator and Developer. The Developer role can be configured or removed all together depending on your needs but the Administrator role can not be changed. The Administrator role can not be modified or removed and it has access to every resource.

section.para: First we will define the list of permissions and what they mean.

row.entry: The role has access to create a type resource.
The role has access to read a type of resource.
The role has access to modify a type of resource.
The role has access to delete a type of resource.

section.para: These permissions apply to every resource exposed by the Restful APIs. Once a role is defined it can be specified for new Account resources that are created.

note.para: If no role is specified when creating a new Account resource then the new Account will inherit the security role of the account that created it. If this role is the Administrator role the system may become compromised.

formalpara.title: Wildcard Permission
formalpara.para: The asterisk '*' is a wildcard that means grant all permissions and can be used in place of typing out all the permissions.

section.para: To see how this all comes together please check out the restcomm.xml configuration file.

section.title: Dao Manager
section.para: The data access object manager is used to gain access to the data store that TelScale RestComm will use.
The default data access object manager is based on MyBatis and provides access to RDBM systems.

row.entry: The path to the mybatis.xml configuration file.
The path to the data files used to store the database tables.
The path to the XML files containing the SQL statements that will be executed by the database.

section.title: Media Server Manager
section.para: The media server manager is responsible for all the media servers managed by TelScale RestComm.

row.entry: The local IP address for the MGCP stack.
The local port for the MGCP stack.
The IP address for the media server.
The port for the media server.
In milliseconds the maximum amount of time to wait for a response from the media server before abandoning the request. This does NOT apply to RQNT/NOTIFY request/response.

Sometimes there is interest to use a different address in the SDP than the IP address the media server is reporting. This parameter if set tells TelScale RestComm to patch the Connection attribute in the SDP on behalf of the media server to the specified IP address. Note: TelScale RestComm will only do NAT resolution when necessary so if your server already has a routable IP address setting this parameter will have no effect.

section.title: SMS Aggregator
section.para: The SMS aggregator is responsible for the handling of SMS messages on behalf of TelScale RestComm.

formalpara.title: Requirements
formalpara.para: The default SMS aggregator is SMS over IP as used by VoIP Innovations. Therefore, an account must be created @ http://www.voipinnovations.com before any text messages can be sent.

section.para: Below is a list of settings that must be configured to send text messages.

row.entry: A string that you would like to prepend to the destination address. For example, to use service from VoIP Innovations a '#' must be prepended to every destination address.
The SIP endpoint to which outbound SMS messages should be sent. Note: Do not prepend sip: to the endpoint.

section.title: Fax Service
section.para: The fax service sends faxes out on behalf of TelScale RestComm.

formalpara.title: Requirements
formalpara.para: The default fax service is provided by Interfax. Therefore, an account must be created @ http://www.interfax.net before any faxes can be sent.

row.entry: The user name used to authenticate with Interfax.
The password used to authenticate with Interfax.

section.title: Speech Recognizer
section.para: This speech recognizer turns speech into text on behalf of TelScale Restcomm.

formalpara.title: Requirements
formalpara.para: The default speech recognizer uses the ASR service provided by iSpeech. Therefore, an account must be created @ http://www.ispeech.org before any speech can be converted to text.

row.entry: The Web API key provided by iSpeech. This is used as an authentication token for the service.

section.title: Speech Synthesizer
section.para: The speech synthesizer turns text to speech on behalf of TelScale RestComm.

formalpara.title: Requirements
formalpara.para: The default speech synthesizer uses the TTS service provided by VoiceRSS. Therefore, an account must be created @ http://www.voicerss.org before any text can be converted to speech.

row.entry: The API key used to authenticate with the VoiceRSS.
A list of male and female speakers for different languages. These can be replaced with other alternatives provided by VoiceRSS.
